blog.name: roleingthrough
blog.title: Critical Role Live Listen
blog.description: I've broken down and decided to start listening to Critical Role. However, with so much content I need something to motivate me, and I feel like liveblogging the experience is as good an option as any. THIS IS A NO SPOILERS ZONE FOR ME but like, presumably there will be spoilers at some point.

summary: Introductions are in order
body:
Introductions are in order

Like a good chunk of DND nerds my first true introduction to what it could look like came through The Adventure Zone roughly a year and a half ago. I was familiar with the McElroys through MBMBAM and while previously the sheer number of rules had intimidated me away from anything DND related, I figured it would be carried through by my enjoyment of the players.

I had heard of Critical Role, obviously, but the large amount of content had been a deterrent, as well as the fact that I was unfamiliar with pretty much everyone in game except Matt Mercer.

Since then though, I’ve not only binged through Balance, but I’ve participated in a few campaigns myself and am even thinking of GMing a Monster of the Week campaign. I’ve developed an appreciation for role-playing games independent of a McElroy context, so with that I’ve decided it’s finally time to tackle this absolute behemoth. And I also figured that it could be useful to create a space for newer fans like myself, who are just jumping on with the series and are wary of diving into too much fan content for fear of spoilers.

I’ll be starting with Vox Machina and will probably be dealing with primarily the podcast since my attention span for three hours of watching people play a game isn’t great.

So with that, let’s get….role-ing.

….

I wish I had better sign-offs

tags: i dunno y'all. jester is thirsty for beau being a lowkey Romance Novel Love Interest
summary: slow burn
title: slow burn
body:
If she had to guess, Jester would say it probably happened sometime between that one conversation on a stormy night at sea, and the moment Beauregard tears out the beating heart of the eldritch horror-flavored bull monster. Yeah, it must have been somewhere in between those two things that Jester started… Uh. Noticing Beau. In some maybe not-so-sisterly slash best-friendly ways, maybe.

Like, were Beau’s morning workouts always so impressive, with the hundred push-ups she made look effortless, and the pull-ups and stretching exercises that hiked her shirt up to reveal even more of her toned abs glistening with the faintest sheen of sweat? Did she always end those workouts with this careless, cocky grin tossed over her shoulder, and did that little quirk of her mouth always look so damn sexy?

Were Beau’s eyes always so blue when she laughed, her skin so warm and brown beneath the white sun? And Jester’s always admired the way Beau dodged hits and weaved her way in and out of combat, but did she never notice the sheer grace with which she moved, the downright gallant way Beau threw herself ahead of her friends into battle, attracting the enemies’ attention and materializing at Jester or Caleb or Nott’s side whenever they needed her most? Did Beau always carry herself with this ruffled, rakish handsomeness—like a pirate prince from Jester’s books, cocksure and kind, extending a hand to pull Caduceus up to his feet after a hard battle, teasing and jabbing Fjord at the same time as she tosses him a healing potion from her own rations? Was it always so endearing how Beau winks and flirts with Yasha, leaning back with arms folded trying to be cool only to dissolve into stumbled words and self-deprecating laughter? Did Jester’s heart always squeeze and ache when she watched the two of them together, when she thought about Yasha rolling her eyes fondly and lifting Beau into her arms?

These are the kinds of problems Jester ponders as they recover after the near-disastrous fight beneath the well, her shoulder pressed into Caduceus’s side, his warmth and steady breathing reminding her he’s alive, alive, they’re all alive. Including Beauregard, who—apart from being drenched in monster blood and guts, bits of gore still smeared across her face despite her best efforts to wipe herself clean—appears more or less unharmed for once. Relatively speaking.

She makes her way over to the clerics, and Jester’s staring at her maybe a bit too much as she crouches down and claps a hand on Clay’s shoulder, some silent exchange passing between them as they gaze at each other for a long moment before breaking into mirrored grins. Some of Beau’s hair has fallen out of her topknot. There are strands pressed to her forehead with sweat and blood, some dark brown locks falling into her eyes or curling around her ears. And Jester stares.

Beau’s eyes dart from Caduceus over to Jester, and suddenly she is staring back. Her grin softens into a frail, gentle smile, the one Jester secretly suspects is reserved for her and her alone.

“You alright there, Jes?” she says, quiet.

And as Jester notices her, the crook of her smile and the light of her eyes and the way she wears the scars of the last battle like a silk cloak, a second skin—she thinks maybe it started happening earlier than that night on the ship, earlier than she ever thought. Maybe it happened when they slept wrapped together with Kiri cuddled between them, or when Beau carefully tucked a blanket around her in Alfield as if Jester was the most important person in the world, or when she gave her the healer’s kit in Trostenwald with a roll of her eyes and a fond smirk. Maybe it’s been happening all along.

“Everything’s fine,” says Jester, with a slow smile. “Thank you for asking.”

“You alright there, Jes?” she says, quiet.

And as Jester notices her, the crook of her smile and the light of her eyes and the way she wears the scars of the last battle like a silk cloak, a second skin—she thinks maybe it started happening earlier than that night on the ship, earlier than she ever thought. Maybe it happened when they slept wrapped together with Kiri cuddled between them, or when Beau carefully tucked a blanket around her in Alfield as if Jester was the most important person in the world, or when she gave her the healer’s kit in Trostenwald with a roll of her eyes and a fond smirk. Maybe it’s been happening all along.

“Everything’s fine,” says Jester, with a slow smile. “Thank you for asking.”

blog.description: It's always in the last place you look for it.

blog.name: concept-stage
blog.description:
AO3 I'm open for fic prompts.
she/her, You can call me Denni,
I live blog Critical Role every week.
I tag spoilers as 'Critical Role spoilers' until the new episode comes out on youtube.

summary: Marisha getting excited and accidentally clocking Liam in the face is the most Empire Siblings thing imaginable tbh
question: Marisha getting excited and accidentally clocking Liam in the face is the most Empire Siblings thing imaginable tbh
answer:
True, lol. Unarmed strike, take 11 points of damage.

—–

“Are you sure this is the best idea?” Caleb mumbled, leaning over to talk right in Beau’s ear. Beau waved dismissively and shushed him. “I’m just saying, didn’t you tell me that she lost all her money doing exactly this the day you first met her?”

Beau shushed him again. “She’s come a long way since then.”

Caleb watched Jester making faces at the man she was playing cards with whenever he looked away. “Has she?” he asked, raising an eyebrow. “Has she really?”

Jester hummed happily and kept grinning whenever the man looked up at her and even Caleb couldn’t tell if she was bluffing or not. Apparently, neither could the soldier sitting across from her because he looked way too confident.

“Read em and weep,” he sneered, laying down his cards. Caleb didn’t know enough about this game to tell if it was a good hand or not. There were a lot of people with crowns. He started to reach for the pot of money in the middle but Jester interrupted him.

“Ah, ah, ah,” she teased, laying down her own cards.

Caleb leaned forward to try and get a good look at the cards and Beau whopped, throwing up her arms. Caleb wasn’t sure what happened at first, there was a flare of pain on his chin and his eyes crossed a bit, and it felt like his brain was getting thrown around in his head like a hacky sack.

“Oh shit!” Beau exclaimed. When his vision started to clear, Beau reached over and pressed her hand over his chin, pulling him in close and hugging around his shoulders so that he didn’t fall down. “Are you alright? Sorry, man.”

“I… think.” There were two Beau’s right now, which was pretty much a nightmare, but when his eyes cleared completely it went back to just one. “Did you hit me?”

“It was an accident! Don’t tell Nott!”
